SafetyInspectionBy: KS State Boiler Inspection/KS State Fire Marshall

_prev_prog_3.Description: NGL Fractionator and Underground Storage Facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ONEOK Hydrocarbon, L.P.

Bushton Complex

Bushton, Kansas



E X E C U T I V E    S U M M A R Y



INTRODUCTION AND POLICIES



ONEOK Hydrocarbon, L.P. (ONEOK) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations.  ONEOK's management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.



The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the facility and planned changes to improve safety at the facility.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



ONEOK owns and operates a natural gas liquids (NGL) fractionation plant and underground cavern storage facility located near Bushton, Kansas.  The fractionator and the storage caverns were previously covered under separate Risk Management Plans; however, they are now incorporated into one RMP.  The Bushton Fractionator receives raw natural gas liquids via pipeline, which are then fractionated into various products.  These products include ethane/propane (E/P mix), propane, iso-butane, normal butane, and 14# gasoline.  The storage facility receives products from the fractionator as well as from incoming pipeline and stores the substances in underground storage caverns.  From the storage caverns, products are sent to customers via outgoing pipeline.  Additionally, propane is loaded on trucks for distribution to customers.  The RMP flammable substances and mixtures stored or processed at the facility are E/P mix, propane, iso-butane, normal butane, refiner

y-grade butane, Y-Grade (raw feed), and 14# Gasoline.  There are no toxic substances present at the facility in amounts greater than threshold quantity.  The facility is classified as Program Level 3 under the regulation.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by ONEOK.  These high standards include:

-  Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 

-  Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.

-  Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.

-  Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.



PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Bushton Complex is operating under the guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.    Part of the RMP/PSM Prevention Program involves identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:

- Providing overpressure relief valves on all pressurized vessels.

- Providing level transmitters and alarms on all vessels to help prevent overfilling.

- Conducting preventive maintenance and testing of vessels through the Mechanical   Integrity program to help ensure   that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.

- Minimizing the possibility of an interruption in the combustion of hydrocarbon vapors by having a continuous flare. 

- Ensuring hydrocarbon vapor is removed and burned by installing degassifiers at the north and south brine systems.

- Installing hydrocarbon gas detectors throughout the gas plant and at every well in the storage facility.

- Minimizing the potential for a catastrophic

event by providing a fire water system throughout the gas plant and in the pipeline area.

- Installing security lighting and surveillance cameras to facilitate observation of the entire facility.

- Minimizing the possibility of emergencies by manning the facility continuously.

- Providing an evacuation alarm system in order to safely evacuate the facility during emergency situations.

- Conducting periodic operational rounds to ensure problems are detected and corrected in a timely manner.   

    

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Bushton Complex has experienced no reportable RMP/PSM incidents under the five-year accident history provision, as defined in the EPA RMP Part 68 regulation.  

    

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

    

The facility will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary with the Ellsworth and Rice County Local Emergency Planning Committee.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the Ellsworth and Rice County Sheriff Departments and the Holyrood Fire Department.  The Bushton Plant Manager or Manager, Storage Operations is responsible for coordinating the emergency actions depending on where they occur within the facility.  A specific Emergency Response Plan for the facility is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials.  The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program, coupled with the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, forms the framework for continuous safety Improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:

- The Management of Change (MOC) provisions ensures that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.

- The Pro

cess Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.

- The Mechanical Integrity (MI) provisions ensure that process equipment and Instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.

- Contractors entering a ONEOK facility are provided with appropriate safety/emergency action training; and are properly managed while inside RMP/PSM facility boundaries.

- Incident investigation procedures are in place to ensure that corrective measures are taken, if necessary, following an incident. This ensures that process design, operating equipment, and operating and maintenance procedures are evaluated to determine changes needed to prevent recurrence of the Incident.

- Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements.



Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the facility include:

- ONEOK's ongoing dialogue, recurring tabletop exercises or physical emergency drills with the Ellsworth and Rice County Emergency Management Directors or his/her designees will help ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements to emergency response capabilities, as  needs arise.  Protection of the environment, people/public and property is paramount to ONEOK.

- The Bushton Complex has developed an internal company fire brigade and has purchased firefighting equipment to help aid in offensive and defensive emergency response.  Development of emergency response training, ER tool(s) acquisition, and overall response capabilities continues at the Bushton facility.

- For increased security, Bushton Complex Management continues to install perimeter fenc

ing, surveillance cameras and other technology to control facility access/monitoring.

- For mitigation against the potential for large volume flammables release, Bushton Complex Management has installed and continues to install DCS logic-controlled Emergency Block Valves (EBVs) on identified vessels holding 2,000 gallons or more of flammable product(s).

- Bushton Complex Management has proactively completed Fire Proofing Quantitative Risk Assessments with 3rd Party consultants and continues to work towards fire-proofing identified pipe supports, equipment and piping.
